accessibilityMap.PRIMARY: Joel de la Fuente. as Inspector Kido
Louis Ozawa Changchien. as Paul Kasoura
Pippa Mackie. as Coat Check Girl
Anthony Ingram. as Kasoura's House Boy

textMap.PRIMARY: 3. Lem teaches his boy how to fish
5. Juliana breaks the news to her parents about Trudy
6. Ed warns Frank about the Japanese
8. Frank pressures Robert to go through with the plan
9. Juliana reaches out to Karen on Joe's behalf
10. John overhears Helen cancelling her social appointment for Thomas
11. Karen and Lem go to the pickup point
12. Kanagawa attempts to sell information to Kido and Yoshida
13. Dr. Adler gives John the diagnosis for his son
16. Heydrich surprises John with a visit
18. Robert has trouble getting into the door
19. John is suspicious of Connolly before questioning Wegener
20. Robert shows Paul and Betty the necklace
21. Karen comes back with a deal
22. Robert brings Frank his cut from the deal
23. Thomas returns from a run and John takes a call from Joe
24. Frank is prepared for the Neutral Zone
25. John looks through old photos of his brother
26. Karen and Lem pick up Joe
28. Juliana and Frank have a last meal with her parents
29. The plan gets set into motion

accessibilityMap.PRIMARY: Lem Washington. acted by Rick Worthy
Ed McCarthy. acted by DJ Qualls
Inspector Kido. acted by Joel de la Fuente
Sergeant Yoshida. acted by Lee Shorten
Arnold Walker. acted by Daniel Roebuck
Juliana Crain. acted by Alexa Davalos
Anne Walker. acted by Macall Gordon
Frank Frink. acted by Rupert Evans
Joe Blake. acted by Luke Kleintank
Robert Childan. acted by Brennan Brown
Helen Smith. acted by Chelah Horsdal
John Smith. acted by Rufus Sewell
Thomas Smith. acted by Quinn Lord
Jennifer Smith. acted by Genea Charpentier
Amy Smith. acted by Gracyn Shinyei
Nobusuke Tagomi. acted by Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa
Rudolph Wegener. acted by Carsten Norgaard

textMap.PRIMARY: You Better Watch What You Do
Save the Last Dance for Me
The filming location where Lem and his son fish is the Burnaby Lake located in Burnaby, BC.

During WWII, communications within the resistance movements always posed a problem. All mail, telephone, telegrams, and radio communications were closely monitored and easily intercepted. In order to make this work, seemingly innocuous statements containing a hidden meaning were placed in telephone and letter correspondence. Couriers were a vital way of transporting coded information and postal workers were an asset to the resistance movement. One popular way of transporting coded information was to write the code on cigarette paper, wrap it around a needle and insert it into a cigarette.
The replica of Chief Sitting Bull's necklace was created by "The Man in the High Castle" prop maker, Levi Woods.
Sand casting is the process in which you make a metal casting mold using sand as the mold element.
Summary execution is when an execution is carried out swiftly, without trial or any full legal proceedings.
In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," 'Three Yellow Daisies' is a password that Karen told Juliana to use if she wanted to see her.

Thought to be written in Old English over 1000 years ago, this epic poem is a classic story of triumph over evil. Over 3000 lines long, it tells the story Beowulf, a Geatish prince, who sets sail to Denmark to defeat the monster, Grendal, who is terrorizing the kingdom. After Grendal is slain, her mother takes her revenge by attacking the King's hall where she and Beowulf become locked in a vicious fight. Once again, Beowulf is victorious. But now, 50 years later, Beowulf has to defeat a dragon that has been guarding a treasure-trove. True to form, he defeats the dragon, but is fatally wounded in the battle.

The author of Beowulf remains unknown, as it is likely to have been orally passed down through spoken storytelling for many generations. The most famous translation is Seamus Heaney's, which won the Whitbread Book of the Year Award in 1999.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," Beowulf would be a standard text in school, with Hitler himself having studied it as a child. He was inspired by the legend's philosophies of racial superiority and the outcasts who had no place in the Fatherland.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," 'Aryan Literature' is a school subject much like 'English Literature'. It is the study of literature approved by the Reich. In the Third Reich, education was focused on racial superiority, physical fitness, and anti-intellectualism. Parents were encouraged to strictly monitor the reading materials of their children.

In 1962, the conversion of 100,000 JPY to USD would be $830.13. In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," this value would change as the Yen would be much stronger on account of Japan winning the war.

Landouzy-Dejerine disease, otherwise known as facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy, is a hereditary muscles wasting disease, most commonly affecting the face, shoulders, upper arms and lower legs initially. Symptoms usually appear during teenage years. The genetic cause of the disease is yet to be identified.

In order to 'cleanse' the Aryan race of anyone considered a financial burden on the state, Hitler encouraged physicians to grant a 'Mercy Death' on those considered either mentally or physically incurable. This idea had been debated as early as the 1920's when the economy had been at a low point post WWI. Often the killing of patients was carried out in secret, with fake ashes and death certificates sent to families.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," the nuclear threat from the Greater Nazi Reich is an ongoing concern for the Japanese. In order to be prepared, it is important for them to mine for Uranium to produce nuclear energy.

Historically, the rank of Oberstgruppenfhrer was more of an honorary rank, translated as 'Supreme Group Leader' and one down from the Fhrer. Created in 1942, only 4 people were promoted to this level.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," a hero's welcome would entail a great deal of pomp and circumstance. Heydrich would be met with a parade, marching troops, a full military band, top dignitaries, crowds waving flags, speeches, a presentation of awards, and more.

One of the most well-known acts of treason during the Third Reich was the attempted assassination of Hitler carried out by Colonel Claus von Stauffenberg. In June 1944, von Stauffenberg was promoted to Frederich Fromm's Chief of Staff, which gave him access to Hitler's briefing sessions. A month later, after two failed attempts, he carried a bomb concealed in a brief case into a briefing meeting and positioned it under a large oak table, where they were reading maps. When von Stauffenberg left to make a phone call, the bomb detonated, killing four people. Hitler was not one of them. Von Stauffenberg, alongside his fellow conspirators, was rounded up and executed.
As in the book of "The Man in the High Castle," Wu is a Chinese word that means wisdom or comprehension. In Japanese, the term is Satori.

During Hitler's reign the term "Lebensraum," translated in English to "living space," became an ideology of the Nazi nation. The principle behind Lebensraum was for Nazi Germany to expand into Eastern Europe by overtaking their countries, exterminating their peoples and re-populating their lands with the racial superiority of the Germanic people. The execution of this philosophy resulted in the Holocaust. Once Germany took occupation of France, Alsace and Lorrain they began their racial restructuring. In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," this ideology would be as present as ever. The Nazis would infuse it into key propaganda materials such as: newspapers, magazines, and television. Thus utilizing the word "Leben" translating in English to "living" as the name of the Greater Nazi Reich newspaper.

Germany adopted the metric system in 1871. In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," the Greater Nazi Reich would have brought this system over to America with the occupation.

Despite the metric system having been legal in the US since 1866, it is very rarely used. This is unlike all other industrialized nations, despite the voluntary measures passed by the government. This is because the general consensus is that, at this stage, it would be too costly (NASA have estimated this cost at $370 million) and not necessary.

Until recently, Foley Street in London was home to the offices of Big Light Productions. Big Light is the production company of "The Man in the High Castle's" Executive Producer/Writer, Frank Spotnitz. It is also a real street in San Francisco.
The filming location where Lem and his son fish is the Burnaby Lake located in Burnaby, BC.

One popular way of transporting coded information was to write the code on cigarette paper, wrap it around a needle and insert it into a cigarette.
The replica of Chief Sitting Bull's necklace was created by "The Man in the High Castle" prop maker, Levi Woods.
